title: Vassily Kalinnikov: The Two Symphonies - MPO, Kees Bakels (2011)

VASSILY KALINNIKOV (1866-1901)
The Two Symphonies

"These performances are at least as fine as any by Russian ensembles, and they are surely better recorded. Vassily Kalinnikovâ€™s symphonies hover on the edge of the repertoire, but they are very beautiful worksâ€“a touch stiff formally, perhaps, but melodically extremely attractive, and very, very Russian. They actually sound a bit similar, but all that means is that if you like one, youâ€™ll like the other just as much. Neither outstays its welcome; both fit on a single CD lasting a touch over 77 minutes.
Kees Bakels and the orchestra, as with the Rimsky-Korsakov recordings from these forces, make a wholly positive impression. The strings sing richly in the soaring melodies in the allegros and slow movements; rhythms snap with the requisite tang in the two scherzos. Bakels pays special attention to details of color and balance: listen to how sensitively the ticking harp in the First symphonyâ€™s slow movement underpins the musical discourse. Itâ€™s truly poetic. If you want these works in modern sound, this is the disc to get." --David Hurwitz
